title: Hard numbers in the Wayland vs. X11 input latency discussion
dot:
digraph WaylandInputLatency{rankdir=TB;node[shape=rect, style=filled, fillcolor=lightgrey, fontsize=10, fontname="Arial"]; A[label="Wayland vs X11 Input Latency Experiment"];B[label="Motivation:
Perceived cursor lag under Wayland"];C[label="Experiment Design:
- 240 FPS video recording
- Compared Wayland and X11 sessions"];D[label="Hardware Details:
AMD Ryzen 9 5950X
AMD Radeon RX 7900XT
Gigabyte M32U
Logitech G502
iPhone 15 Pro"];E[label="Limitations:
- 240 FPS not high enough for 144Hz
- Pixel transition ambiguity
- Duplicate frames in video"];F[label="Results:
- Wayland has ~6.5ms more latency
- Close to 1 full screen refresh"];G[label="Conclusion:
- Difference is noticeable
- Further testing needed"];H[label="Caveats:
- Only tested GNOME compositor
- Results may vary with different hardware"];A->B;A->C;C->D;C->E;A->F;F->G;F->H;}

title: AI slop, suspicion, and writing back
dot: digraph AI_Slop{rankdir=LR;node[shape=box, style="rounded"]; A[label="Main Idea: Recognition of AI-Generated Content"]; B1[label="The Rise of AI Slop"];B2[label="Slop in the Wild"];B3[label="Slop Paranoia"];B4[label="Write for Future AIs"];B5[label="Finding a Path Forward"]; C1[label="Definition of Slop: Content passed off as human-written"];C2[label="Examples: Robotic posts, 20-tweet threads"];C3[label="Subconscious detection of AI content"];C4[label="Influencing future AI outputs"];C5[label="Curating quality sources of content"]; D1[label="AI Slop = Spam for AI-generated content"];D2[label="Critical thinking needed to spot slop"];D3[label="Personal experiences with slop detection"];D4[label="Writing to influence AI's understanding"];D5[label="Advice: Use RSS, find real discussions"]; A->B1;A->B2;A->B3;A->B4;A->B5; B1->C1;B1->C2; B2->D1;B2->D2; B3->D3; B4->D4; B5->D5;}
